Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Christopher Vogl is "A Three-Dimensional Model of a Lipid Vesicle with Solute Transport." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Washington, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Randall LeVeque.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has yielded new computational techniques that will allow for more accurate simulation of physical phenomena in less time.  Two such techniques better simulate how a physical interface moves with and reacts to the surrounding environment.  When these techniques are combined, they enable the simulation of cell membranes undergoing various drying processes that biologists will use to guide the development of lyopreservation methods. These methods, unlike cryopreservation, do not require extremely cold temperatures.  Another technique that resulted from the project will allow mechanical and civil engineers simulate the flow of fluid, such as oil in a pipe, at a fraction of the computational cost.  A final technique produced by the project allows for the simulation of the ocean both during and after an earthquake.  When an earthquake occurs under the seafloor, a tsunami is usually generated that can have devastating effects on coastline populations.  Monitoring instrumentation and early warning systems are currently designed to detect tsunamis that were created far away.  The results of this project will now enable simulation of tsunamis resulting from earthquakes close to the US coastline. These simulations will help provide warning system with better, more tailored instrumentation.

The project has also contributed to ensuring the next generation of scientists will have the mathematical and computational backgrounds needed to tackle today's problems. However, having the tools is not enough: the next generation of scientists needs to be familiar with a variety of application areas to know where to apply what tool. By the means of introductory computational courses that use mathematical models as examples, the project introduced students from biology, chemistry, history, and other areas to the techniques of applied mathematics.  As a result, they are now in computational graduate programs that will enable them to return to their original application areas with tools not usually found among biologists, chemists, and historians.
